etymology.description: Inverted 曰 (“to speak”), yielding a form like 亼 with an added bottom stroke; the inverted ‘mouth’ signifies ‘not to speak’. Another view: it depicts something in the mouth (cf. 噤, 吟), with 含 as a derivative of the original word.
etymology.interpretation: Graphically portrays the idea of speech being suppressed or something held in the mouth. The form was later associated by sound with the temporal word meaning ‘now; today’, which became the primary modern sense.

examples.chinese: 今后我们要多联系(今後我們要多聯繫)。
examples.english: From now on we should stay in touch more.

examples.chinese: 从今以后再也不迟到(從今以後再也不遲到)。
examples.pinyin: Cóng jīn yǐhòu zàiyě bù chídào.
examples.english: From today onward I will never be late again.

examples.chinese: 如今很少有人写信了(如今很少有人寫信了)。
examples.pinyin: Rújīn hěn shǎo yǒu rén xiě xìn le.
